5.3 The Book on Spirit and Soul

J.L. Teicher argues that Isaac Israeli is not the author of this work
(Teicher, 1956 p. 424). However, since Israeli’s pupil Dunash
Ibn Tamim quotes passages of it in his commentary on the mystical work
Sefer Yetzirah, Teicher’s view is likely erroneous.

Two Hebrew translations (Sefer ha-Ruah v’ha-Nefesh) and
a fragment of the Arabic original remain of this work. Altmann and
Stern provide a critical English translation based on the Hebrew
manuscripts (Munich Steinschneider’s Cat. no. 307, fols. 47ff;
Cambridge Addler 1858 fols. 113v ff.) and A. Borisov’s
publication of the Arabic fragment in Isaac Israeli, pp.
108–117.

This treatise, unlike the Book of Definitions and Book of
Substances is a distinctly Jewish work of philosophy, as it
combines doctrines of soul drawn from Ibn Hasday’s Neoplatonist
with Jewish scriptural proof texts, supporting a Neoplatonist
conception of soul as distinct from mortal spirit, combined with the
Rabbinic Jewish belief in reward and punishment of souls.
